prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-Angular resolution Since OJ287 shows bright knot/hotspot in kpc-scale (arcsec scale) while we are interested in the unresolved core. To discriminate these kpc-scale components, we require the angular resolution better than 1arcsec.
-Sensitivity Source flux density is estimated from the recent flux measurement at 43GHz (~1.3Jy) by extrapolating with a spectral index of 0.5. We require the image sensitivity to detect these source with a level of 20sigma and 10sigma for band 3 and bands 6/7, respectively, in order to make the flux error due to the thermal noise less significant as compared to the flux calibration error (5% in band 3, 10% in bands 6 and 7). Note that estimated flux density by this method is two times higher than the one indicated in desired sensitivity per pointing for following reason: OT allows to select only aggregate bandwith in single continuum mode, but we need to achieve the signal-to-noise ratio written above in each spw. For this reason, desired sensitivity written above is devided by 2 (=sqrt(4)) to be equivalent to the per-spw basis signal-to-noise ratio.
-spectral setup A number of frequency data is required to minimize the error in spectral index (alpha). We demonstrated the Monte Carlo simulation by adding 5% systematic error in flux for band 3 and 10% for bands 6 and 7 (Propose's guide) to estimate the accuracy. If we put 4 spectral windows (spws) for each band, it is possible to measure the alpha between band 3 and band 6 with an accuracy of < 0.1. On the other hand, it is difficult to discriminate optically thick (alpha~0) or thin (alpha~0.5) between band 6 and band 7 if we put only 4 spws in these bands. Thus, we will increase the number of spws by changing the LO frequency in bands 6 and 7. We can achieve an accuracy of < 0.15 between band 6 and band 7 if we put 8 spws for each band. For this reason, we prepare two science goals for bands 6 and 7. We require 5 frequencies in total.
-Special request A rapid time variation within a timescale of days to weeks has been detected in all target sources. The multi-frequency flux measurements must be carried out within 1 day. Therefore, ScienceGoals OJ287_B3, OJ287_B6a, OJ287_B6b, OJ287_B7a, OJ287_B7b should be carried out within one day. We attempt very accurate spectral calibration to reduce systematic errors in flux calibration between bands. We will add two bright quasars in each SB and check the flux calibration validity by comparing between observed flux densities of these quasars and ALMA Grid Survey/SMA monitoring. The averaged spectrum of observed more than one calibrator (quasars) can have small individual spectral characters and show systematic offsets in amplitude scale among bands. This method was already emploied in our Cycle 0 project (PI: A. Doi) and we confirmed this method is useful. We also prefer to choose solar system object (not quasar) for the flux calibrator.

-Angular resolution We do not have special requests for angular resolution since this source does not show any significant extended feature in arcsec scale. Any configuration is acceptable.
-Sensitivity Source flux density is estimated from the recent flux measurement at 22GHz (~0.94Jy) by extrapolating with a spectral index of 0.5. We require the image sensitivity to detect these source with a level of 20sigma and 10sigma for band 3 and bands 6/7, respectively, in order to make the flux error due to the thermal noise less significant as compared to the flux calibration error (5% in band 3, 10% in bands 6 and 7). -spectral setup A number of frequency data is required to minimize the error in spectral index (alpha). For this reason, we prepare two science goals for bands 6 and 7. We require 5 frequencies in total.

-Special request A rapid time variation within a timescale of days to weeks has been detected in all target sources. The multi-frequency flux measurements must be carried out within 1 day Therefore, ScienceGoals 2005-489_B3, 2005-489_B6a, 2005-489_B6b, 2005-489_B7a, 2005-489_B7b should be carried out within one day. We attempt very accurate spectral calibration to reduce systematic errors in flux calibration between bands. We will add two bright quasars in each SB and check the flux calibration validity by comparing between observed flux densities of these quasars and ALMA Grid Survey/SMA monitoring. The averaged spectrum of observed more than one calibrator (quasars) can have small individual spectral characters and show systematic offsets in amplitude scale among bands. This method was already emploied in our Cycle 0 project (PI: A. Doi) and we confirmed this method is useful. We also prefer to choose solar system object (not quasar) for the flux calibrator.

-Angular resolution Since this object shows bright knot/hotspot in kpc-scale (arcsec scale) while we are interested in the unresolved core. To discriminate these kpc-scale components, we require the angular resolution better than 1 arcsec.
-Sensitivity Source flux density is estimated from the recent flux measurement at 8.4GHz (130mJy) by extrapolating with a spectral index of 0.5. We require the image sensitivity to detect these source with a level of 20sigma and 10sigma for band 3 and bands 6/7, respectively, in order to make the flux error due to the thermal noise less significant as compared to the flux calibration error (5% in band 3, 10% in bands 6 and 7). Note that estimated flux density by this method is two times higher than the one indicated in desired sensitivity per pointing for following reason: OT allows to select only aggregate bandwith in single continuum mode, but we need to achieve the signal-to-noise ratio written above in each spw. For this reason, desired sensitivity written above is devided by 2 (=sqrt(4)) to be equivalent to the per-spw basis signal-to-noise ratio.
-spectral setup A number of frequency data is required to minimize the error in spectral index (alpha). We demonstrated the Monte Carlo simulation by adding 5% systematic error in flux for band 3 and 10% for bands 6 and 7 (Propose's guide) to estimate the accuracy. If we put 4 spectral windows (spws) for each band, it is possible to measure the alpha between band 3 and band 6 with an accuracy of < 0.1. On the other hand, it is difficult to discriminate optically thick (alpha~0) or thin (alpha~0.5) between band 6 and band 7 if we put only 4 spws in these bands. Thus, we will increase the number of spws by changing the LO frequency in bands 6 and 7. We can achieve an accuracy of < 0.15 between band 6 and band 7 if we put 8 spws for each band. For this reason, we prepare two science goals for bands 6 and 7. We require 5 frequencies in total.
-Special request A rapid time variation within a timescale of days to weeks has been detected in all target sources. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe 4 BL-Lac-type blazars at 5 frequencies in bands 3, 6, and 7 to construct the mm/submm spectrum. Goal of this proposal is to identify the optically-thick to optically-thin transition of the emission from the jet in the close vicinity of the central engine. Our preparatory study indicates that most of blazars show the transition around ALMA band 3 or band 6, while the previous one-zone SED modeling predicts the transition in far-infrared bands. This strongly suggests that the conventional one-zone SED modeling is not valid. An alternative model, which can reconcile this discrepancy, is multi-zone scenario such as stratified jet model, i.e., the high energy gamma-ray emission from the spine and radio emission from the sheath of the jet. This will give a new understanding for the anatomy and particle acceleration theory in AGN jets. By adding our Cycle 0 and ongoing Cycle 1 study towards FSRQ-type blazars, we will clarify the universality of the one-zone break in different type of blazars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00729.S, Millimeter and Submillimeter Spectrum of 3C 454.3 in the Close Vicinity of the Central Engine, Hiroshi Nagai
